item.title: Multi-threading system
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:19, topic:529514”]Okay then.

You are practically rewriting this: http://grepcode.com/file/repository.grepcode.com/java/root/jdk/openjdk/6-b14/java/util/concurrent/ExecutorService.java

But that is done in a much better fashion. You need to scrap this and be MORE specific in the way this interacts with your designs because your implementation is too generic.

The only difference I note is that your implementation allows for the task to control when it stops being executed, which honestly could be implemented with a Future or Future return statement. Or even a CUSTOM task system (this is not named correctly and would make any other programmer think of a thread executor hence the whole rewriting) where the class task that is implemented has a flag for if the boss controller should remove the task from the iterable list of tasks that are current set to be executed every X timeframe.

You need to think deeper into your setup of responsibility and flow of information.[/quote]
That was actually wonderful constructive criticism. I would praise you more for it, but it should be the norm if you feel you wish to say anything negative at all towards beginners.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @iz3_legend iz3 legend
item.description:
@iz3_legend wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:21, topic:529514”]See your bullshit attitude of questioning my knowledge has me on the ropes of believing you’re a retarded kid who is just learning how to program and doesn’t help me wanting to assist SPECIFICALLY you. You act penisy, you aren’t a good programmer and you question the current powers at large. Hence why I treat you worse than those who are just starting out to learn.

Also considering you don’t understand the term ‘generic’ in way I’ve said it is a good indication of your skill level.

[code]
Okay then.

You are practically rewriting this: http://grepcode.com/file/repository.grepcode.com/java/root/jdk/openjdk/6-b14/java/util/concurrent/ExecutorService.java

But that is done in a much better fashion. You need to scrap this and be MORE specific in the way this interacts with your designs because your implementation is too generic.

The only difference I note is that your implementation allows for the task to control when it stops being executed, which honestly could be implemented with a Future or Future return statement. Or even a CUSTOM task system (this is not named correctly and would make any other programmer think of a thread executor hence the whole rewriting) where the class task that is implemented has a flag for if the boss controller should remove the task from the iterable list of tasks that are current set to be executed every X timeframe.

You need to think deeper into your setup of responsibility and flow of information.
[/code][/quote]

Because you have a badge you cant be questioned, your an all knowing and all seeing power? I appreciate the ACTUAL criticism and will take note of it. I don’t see why you couldn’t have posted this the first time.

"Java Generics" is a technical term denoting a set of language features related to the definition and use of generic types and methods . Generic types or methods differ from regular types and methods in that they have type parameters.

item.title: Multi-threading system
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

See your bullshit attitude of questioning my knowledge has me on the ropes of believing you’re a retarded kid who is just learning how to program and doesn’t help me wanting to assist SPECIFICALLY you. You act cocky, you aren’t a good programmer and you question the current powers at large. Hence why I treat you worse than those who are just starting out to learn.

Also considering you don’t understand the term ‘generic’ in way I’ve said it is a good indication of your skill level.

Okay then.

You are practically rewriting this: http://grepcode.com/file/repository.grepcode.com/java/root/jdk/openjdk/6-b14/java/util/concurrent/ExecutorService.java

But that is done in a much better fashion. You need to scrap this and be MORE specific in the way this interacts with your designs because your implementation is too generic.

The only difference I note is that your implementation allows for the task to control when it stops being executed, which honestly could be implemented with a Future<Boolean> or Future<SomeEnum> return statement. Or even a CUSTOM task system (this is not named correctly and would make any other programmer think of a thread executor hence the whole rewriting) where the class task that is implemented has a flag for if the boss controller should remove the task from the iterable list of tasks that are current set to be executed every X timeframe. 

You need to think deeper into your setup of responsibility and flow of information.

Read full topic

item.title: Multi-threading system
item.dc:creator: @iz3_legend iz3 legend
item.description:
@iz3_legend wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:19, topic:529514”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=648269.msg4361276#msg4361276 date=1378782836]

that’d be a waste of my time

Based on this comment and the past few I’ve seen, I think sini should have his ‘java guru’ emblem revoked. He’s really not even a guru. He might be educated in the field, but he offers little to no knowledge or constructive criticism; far from a guru.
[/quote]

Not…even…a guru? We’re not obligated to help anyone. I was given the award for RSPS work I did way before I got good at java. The old java gurus were WAY worse in their criticism than I ever am so sit down. I got all my projects ripped apart and it improved me, they didn’t even post constructive criticism they were just asshats.

This is trash because its an implementation for something you don’t even really need. It could be simplified and exported. It’s too generic, and Im guessing OP had no idea what he was going to use this for before he wrote it.

So before you question if I deserve this badge that Ive had now for almost two years I suggest you sit down and make a better example of yourself because you are treading on toes that have and actively try and progress the community further. It’s not our obligation to help people.

that’d be a waste of my time

Bro, that’s not cool. We’re all here to learn, don’t be so damn penisy, lead him in the right direction, just because he criticized your snippet or whatever doesn’t mean you need to blacklist him; he asked for a better way to do it, why can you not share the knowledge? You seem to always find time to assist me when I have a question but when it’s on the forum your ego takes over (or t least it seems like it). Dude fudge your ego, stop being greedy and nogalistic. We were all beginners once, the least you could do would be to help out the lower class. Regardless of what they have done in the past.

I don’t like his attitude therefore I will circumvent any sort of constructive criticism I have. See reasons as to why this is trash above.[/quote]

Your right, there’s absolutely no reason to ever process things on multiple threads in an application. To generic…? Do you understand even the basics of generics?

You said it could be simplified and exported, i’d urge you to elaborate on this which you have once again failed to-do in your previous post. I’d be more than happy to accept any criticism if you could ever manage to provide any.

WAY worse in their criticism
Implying that they actually provided criticism.. unlike you.

Read full topic

item.title: Multi-threading system
item.dc:creator: @iz3_legend iz3 legend
item.description:
@iz3_legend wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:6, topic:529514”]Kinda shortened and added some things. I just find it better when it’s shorter and still does the same thing.

[code=java]
package engine.timing.tasks;

import java.util.concurrent.ScheduledExecutorService;

import engine.timing.tasks.ExecutionThreadListener.ExecutionThreadState;

public abstract class ExecutionThread {

private ExecutionThreadState state = ExecutionThreadState.PENDING;
private ScheduledExecutorService service;
private long executionDelay;

public ExecutionThread(long executionDelay) {
	this.setService(ExecutionThreadListener.DEFAULT_SERVICE);
	this.setExecutionDelay(executionDelay);
}

public ExecutionThread(ScheduledExecutorService service, long executionDelay) {
	this.setService(service);
	this.setExecutionDelay(executionDelay);
}

public ExecutionThread(ScheduledExecutorService service, long executionDelay, ExecutionThreadState state){
	this.setService(service);
	this.setExecutionDelay(executionDelay);
	this.setState(state);
}

public abstract void destruct();

public abstract void execute();

public ExecutionThreadState getState() { return state; }

public void setState(ExecutionThreadState state) { this.state = state; }

public ScheduledExecutorService getService() { return service; }

public void setService(ScheduledExecutorService service) { this.service = service; }

public long getExecutionDelay() { return executionDelay; }

public void setExecutionDelay(long executionDelay) { this.executionDelay = executionDelay; }

}[/code]

[code=java]
package engine.timing.tasks;

import java.util.LinkedList;
import java.util.Queue;
import java.util.concurrent.Executors;
import java.util.concurrent.ScheduledExecutorService;
import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;

public class ExecutionThreadListener {

public enum ExecutionThreadState { ACTIVE, PENDING, INACTIVE }

public static final ScheduledExecutorService DEFAULT_SERVICE = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors());
private static final ExecutionThreadListener SINGLETON = new ExecutionThreadListener();
private ScheduledExecutorService mainProcessor = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors());
private Queue<ExecutionThread> executionThreadQueue = new LinkedList<ExecutionThread>();

public synchronized void submit(final ExecutionThread thread) {
	if (thread.getState() == ExecutionThreadState.PENDING) {
		getExecutionThreadQueue().add(thread);
		thread.setState(ExecutionThreadState.ACTIVE);
    }
    thread.getService().scheduleAtFixedRate(new Runnable() {
    	@Override
    	public void run() {
    		if (getExecutionThreadQueue().contains(thread)) {
    			if (thread.getState() == ExecutionThreadState.ACTIVE) {
    				thread.execute();
    			} else {
    				thread.destruct();
    				getExecutionThreadQueue().remove(thread);
    			}
    		} else { thread.setState(ExecutionThreadState.INACTIVE); }
    	}
    }, 0, thread.getExecutionDelay(), TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);
}

public Queue<ExecutionThread> getExecutionThreadQueue() { return executionThreadQueue; }

public ScheduledExecutorService getMainProcessor() { return mainProcessor; }

public void setExecutionThreadQueue(Queue<ExecutionThread> echoQueue) { this.executionThreadQueue = echoQueue; }

public void setMainProcessor(ScheduledExecutorService mainProcessor) { this.mainProcessor = mainProcessor; }

public static ExecutionThreadListener getSingleton() { return SINGLETON; }

}[/code][/quote]

Looks pretty good, but the main processor was the default service. If a thread had a high memory requirement it would define a new service, if it had a low one it would specify the main processor. This way your could have a synchronization between multiple-threads with different services without having to either cram everything into one service or re-write code multiple times over to accommodate new additions.

PS. I actually wrote this for a 2D game but it could be applied anywhere attributes need to be processed.

Read full topic

item.title: Multi-threading system
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

Kinda shortened and added some things. I just find it better when it’s shorter and still does the same thing.

[code=java]
package engine.timing.tasks;

import java.util.concurrent.ScheduledExecutorService;

import engine.timing.tasks.ExecutionThreadListener.ExecutionThreadState;

public abstract class ExecutionThread {

private ExecutionThreadState state = ExecutionThreadState.PENDING;
private ScheduledExecutorService service;
private long executionDelay;

public ExecutionThread(long executionDelay) {
	this.setService(ExecutionThreadListener.DEFAULT_SERVICE);
	this.setExecutionDelay(executionDelay);
}

public ExecutionThread(ScheduledExecutorService service, long executionDelay) {
	this.setService(service);
	this.setExecutionDelay(executionDelay);
}

public ExecutionThread(ScheduledExecutorService service, long executionDelay, ExecutionThreadState state){
	this.setService(service);
	this.setExecutionDelay(executionDelay);
	this.setState(state);
}

public abstract void destruct();

public abstract void execute();

public ExecutionThreadState getState() { return state; }

public void setState(ExecutionThreadState state) { this.state = state; }

public ScheduledExecutorService getService() { return service; }

public void setService(ScheduledExecutorService service) { this.service = service; }

public long getExecutionDelay() { return executionDelay; }

public void setExecutionDelay(long executionDelay) { this.executionDelay = executionDelay; }

}[/code]

[code=java]
package engine.timing.tasks;

import java.util.LinkedList;
import java.util.Queue;
import java.util.concurrent.Executors;
import java.util.concurrent.ScheduledExecutorService;
import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;

public class ExecutionThreadListener {

public enum ExecutionThreadState { ACTIVE, PENDING, INACTIVE }

public static final ScheduledExecutorService DEFAULT_SERVICE = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors());
private static final ExecutionThreadListener SINGLETON = new ExecutionThreadListener();
private ScheduledExecutorService mainProcessor = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors());
private Queue<ExecutionThread> executionThreadQueue = new LinkedList<ExecutionThread>();

public synchronized void submit(final ExecutionThread thread) {
	if (thread.getState() == ExecutionThreadState.PENDING) {
		getExecutionThreadQueue().add(thread);
		thread.setState(ExecutionThreadState.ACTIVE);
    }
    thread.getService().scheduleAtFixedRate(new Runnable() {
    	@Override
    	public void run() {
    		if (getExecutionThreadQueue().contains(thread)) {
    			if (thread.getState() == ExecutionThreadState.ACTIVE) {
    				thread.execute();
    			} else {
    				thread.destruct();
    				getExecutionThreadQueue().remove(thread);
    			}
    		} else { thread.setState(ExecutionThreadState.INACTIVE); }
    	}
    }, 0, thread.getExecutionDelay(), TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);
}

public Queue<ExecutionThread> getExecutionThreadQueue() { return executionThreadQueue; }

public ScheduledExecutorService getMainProcessor() { return mainProcessor; }

public void setExecutionThreadQueue(Queue<ExecutionThread> echoQueue) { this.executionThreadQueue = echoQueue; }

public void setMainProcessor(ScheduledExecutorService mainProcessor) { this.mainProcessor = mainProcessor; }

public static ExecutionThreadListener getSingleton() { return SINGLETON; }

}[/code]
